facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 290 to 292 of 1959 were filed.

facts.text: Appeals brought by special leave against judgment and order dated December 6, 1957 of Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 6, 1957, of the Kerala High Court in Agricultural Income-tax Referred Cases Nos. 15, 18 and 19 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment and order of Kerala High Court in Agricultural Income-tax Referred Cases Nos. 15, 18 and 19 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: in Agricultural Income-tax Referred Cases Nos. 15, 18 and 19 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeals relate to accounting years 1950, 1951 and 1952 corresponding to assessment years 1951-52, 1952-53 and 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals relate to three accounting years 1950, 1951 and 1952  assessment years 1951-52, 1952-53 and 1953-54 .

facts.text: Appellants have rubber plantations.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have rubber plantations and in the accounting year 1950,

facts.text: In accounting year 1950 (assessment year 1951-52), appellants had 3558.84 acres under cultivation, of which 334.64 acres immature rubber trees and 3224.20 acres mature yielding trees.

anchor.surface_text: corresponding to the assessment year 1951-52, the appellants had under cultivation 3558-84 acres out of which 334-64 acres had immature rubber trees growing and the rest i.e. 3224-20 acres mature rubber yielding trees under cultivation.

facts.text: In accounting year 1950, sum of Rs. 19,056-0-9 expended for upkeep and maintenance of immature rubber plantation.

anchor.surface_text: In that year a sum of Rs. 19,056-0-9, which was expended for the upkeep and maintenance of immature portion of the rubber plantation, was allowed by the Agricultural Income tax Tribunal

facts.text: Expenditure of Rs. 19,056-0-9 allowed by Agricultural Income tax Tribunal for 1950, reference made at instance of respondent as No. 18 of 1955 under s. 60(1).

anchor.surface_text: , was allowed by the Agricultural Income tax Tribunal and at the instance of the respondent a reference was made to the High Court under s. 60 1  of the Agricultural Income tax Act  Act XXII of 1950  hereinafter termed the Act and that was reference No. 18 of 1955.

facts.text: In accounting year 1951 (assessment year 1952-53), total area under cultivation 3426.55 acres, 3091.91 acres mature, 334.64 acres immature rubber trees.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year 1951 companyresponding to the assessment year 1952-53 the appellant had under cultivation. a total area of 3426,55 acres of which 3091.91acres were mature rubber yielding trees and 334.64 acres had immature rubber trees.

facts.text: In accounting year 1951, expenditure Rs. 59,271.9-5 for upkeep immature rubber estate.

anchor.surface_text: In that year a sum of Rs. 59,271.9-5 was the expenditure incurred for the upkeep and maintenance of immature portion of the rubber estate.

facts.text: Expenditure Rs. 59,271.9-5 allowed by Tribunal, reference by respondent as No. 19 of 1955 under s.60(1).

anchor.surface_text: That sum was allowed by the Agricultural Income-tax Tribunal and at the instance of the respondent a reference was made under s. 60 1  of the Act to the High Court and that was reference No. 19 of 1955.

facts.text: Agricultural Income-tax Reference No. 15 of 1955 relates to accounting year 1952, assessment year 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: In Agricultural Income-tax Reference No. 15 of 1955 which related to, accounting year 1952 and the assessment year 1953-54,

facts.text: In 1952, area under cultivation 3453.65 acres, 2967.91 mature, 485.74 immature rubber trees.

anchor.surface_text: the area under cultivation was 3453,65 out of which 2967,91 acres had mature rubber yielding trees and 485,74 acres had immature rubber growing trees.

facts.text: In 1952, amount expended on maintenance of immature rubber trees Rs. 42,660.4-1.

anchor.surface_text: In that year the amount expended on the maintenance and tending of the imma- ture rubber trees was Rs. 42,660,4-1.

facts.text: For 1952, Agricultural Income tax Tribunal rejected appellant's claim and disallowed expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, however, the Agricultural Income tax Tribunal rejected the appellants claim and disallowed the expenditure.

facts.text: Reference No.15/1955 stated to High Court at instance of appellant under s.60(1), answered negative against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant a case was stated to the High Court under s. 60 1  of the Act and was answered in the negative and against the appellant.

facts.text: Kerala High Court answered questions in negative against appellant in all references.

anchor.surface_text: In all the references the questions were answered in the negative and against the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 15, 1960 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeals, sets aside High Court judgments, answers questions in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow these appeals, set aside the judgments and orders of the High Court and answer the questions in favour of the appellant in all the three agricultural Income-tax References.

facts.text: Expenditure on upkeep of immature rubber trees claimed as deduction under s.5(j) of Travancore-Cochin Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the main question for decision is whether the amount expended for the upkeep and maintenance of the immature, rubber trees is a permissible deduction under s. 5 j  of the Act.

facts.text: Rubber trees do not yield rubber until about six years old.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that rubber trees do number yield any rubber until they are about six years old.

issues.text: Whether under the Travancore-Cochin Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1950 in calculating the assessable agricultural income of a rubber estate already planted and containing both mature yielding rubber trees and also immature rubber plants which have not come into bearing, the annual expenses incurred for the upkeep and maintenance of such rubber plants are a permissible deduction, and if so, whether the sum of Rs. 42,660-4-1 expended by the assessee in the relevant accounting year 1952 under this head may be deducted?

anchor.surface_text: Whether under the Travancore-Cochin Agricul- tural Income Tax Act, 1950 in calculating the assessable agricultural income of a rubber estate already planted and companytaining both mature yielding rubber trees and also immature rubber plants which have number companye into bearing, the annual expenses incurred for the upkeep and maintenance of such rubber plants, are number a permissible deduction, and if so,

issues.text: Whether the expenses incurred for the maintenance and upkeep of immature rubber trees constitute a permissible deduction within the meaning of s. 5(j) of Act XXII of 1950?

anchor.surface_text: and in the other two the question referred was Whether the expenses incurred for the mainte- nance and upkeep of immature rubber trees companystitute a permissible deduction within the meaning of s. 5 j  of Act XXII of 1950? In all the references the questions were answered

issues.text: whether the amount expended for the upkeep and maintenance of the immature rubber trees is a permissible deduction under s. 5(j) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In all the cases the assessee companypany is the appellant and the main question for decision is whether the amount expended for the upkeep and maintenance of the immature, rubber trees is a permissible deduction under s. 5 j  of the Act. The charging section under the Act is s. 3

issues.text: Whether the expenditure on upkeep and maintenance of immature rubber trees/ plants was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of deriving 'the agricultural income', and whether 'the agricultural income' refers only to the income of the accounting year concerned

anchor.surface_text: S.5 The agricultural income of a person shall be companyputed after making the following deductions, namely- expenditure  number being in the nature of capital expenditure or personal expenses of the assessee  laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of deriving the agricultural income. In regard to this income the High Court held We find it impossible to say that the amounts spent on the upkeep and maintenance of the immature rubber plants were laid out or expended for the purpose of deriving the agricultural income,

arguments.claim: Amounts spent on upkeep and maintenance of immature rubber plants were not laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of deriving the agricultural income, as 'the agricultural income' means only the income obtained in the accounting year concerned.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to this income the High Court held We find it impossible to say that the amounts spent on the upkeep and maintenance of the immature rubber plants were laid out or expended for the purpose of deriving the agricultural income, much less that they were laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for that purpose. The agricultural income, in the conte

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the agricultural income obtained in the accounting year companycerned

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court took an erroneous view; the definite article 'the' does not limit deduction to income-yielding trees in that specific year.

arguments.claim: The expenditure was wholly and exclusively laid out for deriving agricultural income, and 'the agricultural income' refers to income from the plantation estate as a whole, not limited to the accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court has taken an erroneous view of the relevant provision. It is not denied that the expenditure claimed as a deduction was wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of deriving income but the use of the definite article the before agricultural income has given rise to the interpretation that the deduction is to be from the income

arguments.claim: Expenses on immature trees are akin to capital expenditure, analogous to the distinction in Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. CIT between acquisition of asset and earning process.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent relied upon a judgment of this Court in Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal  2  and particularly on a passage at page 983 where Bhagwati J. observed The distinction was thus made between the acquisition of an income-earning asset and the process of the earning of the income. Expenditu

court_response_anchor.surface_text: essee had to pay two further sums as protection fees under the terms of the lease. Those sums were held to be capital expenditure inasm

arguments.court_reasoning: Case has no relevancy; concerned payments for acquiring enduring lease advantage, not upkeep of existing plantation.

arguments.claim: Expenditure on upkeep of immature rubber trees deductible as in Vallambrosa Rubber Co. Ltd. v. Farmer, where whole estate expenses allowed despite only part yielding.

anchor.surface_text: In a somewhat similar case Vallambrosa Rubber Co. Ltd. v. Farmer  1  the expenditure of the kind now claimed was allowed under the corresponding provision of the English Income-tax Act. In that case a rubber company had an estate in which in the year of assessment only 1/7 produced rubber and the other 6/7 was in process of cultivation for the production of rubber. It may be added that rubber trees do not yield any rubber until they are about six years old. The expenditure for the superintendence, weeding etc. incurred by the company in respect of the whole estate including the nonbearing rubber estate was allowed on the ground that in arriving at the assessable profits the assessee was entitled to deduct the expenditure for superintendence, weeding etc. on the whole estate and not only on the 1/7 of such expenditure.

arguments.claim: Assam Bengal Cement case distinguishable; involved capital payments for lease acquisition providing enduring advantage, unlike revenue upkeep of existing rubber plantation.

anchor.surface_text: But that case has no relevancy to the facts of the present case nor has that passage any applicability to the facts of the present case. The question there was whether certain payments made were by way of capital expenditure or revenue expenditure. The assessee acquired a lease from Government for twenty years and in addition to paying the rent and royalties for the lease the assessee had to pay two further sums as protection fees under the terms of the lease. Those sums were held to be capital expenditure inasmuch as they were incurred for the acquisition of an asset or an advantage of enduring nature and were not part of the working or operational expenses for carrying on the business of the assessee.

arguments.claim: Upkeep expenses on entire estate, including immature trees, are revenue expenditure deductible against profits, as part of earning process; non-yielding in one year irrelevant.
Expenses incurred for maintenance and upkeep of immature rubber trees constitute permissible deduction under s.5(j) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and in the other two the question referred was Whether the expenses incurred for the maintenance and upkeep of immature rubber trees constitute a permissible deduction within the meaning of s. 5 j  of Act XXII of 1950?

arguments.court_reasoning: Appeals allowed, High Court judgments set aside, questions answered in favour of appellant.

arguments.claim: Annual expenses for upkeep of immature rubber plants on estate with both mature and immature trees are permissible deduction under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether under the Travancore-Cochin Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1950 in calculating the assessable agricultural income of a rubber estate already planted and containing both mature yielding rubber trees and also immature rubber plants which have not come into bearing, the annual expenses incurred for the upkeep and maintenance of such rubber plants, are not a permissible deduction,

arguments.court_reasoning: Appeals allowed, questions answered yes in favour of appellant.

holdings.text: The amount expended on the upkeep and maintenance of immature rubber trees is a permissible deduction under s. 5(j) of the Travancore-Cochin Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow these appeals, set aside the judgments and orders of the High Court and answer the questions in favour of the appellant in all the three agricultural Income-tax References.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court holds that upkeep expenses on immature trees in an existing plantation qualify as revenue expenditure wholly and exclusively laid out for deriving agricultural income from the entire estate, rejecting limitation to current year's yielding trees.

holdings.text: The High Court took an erroneous view by interpreting 'the agricultural income' in s.5(j) as limited to income obtained in the accounting year concerned from yielding trees only.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court has taken an erroneous view of the relevant provision. It is not denied that the expenditure claimed as a deduction was wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of deriving income but the use of the definite article the before agricultural income has given rise to the interpretation that the deduction is to be from the income

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual interpretation of s.5(j); definite article 'the' does not restrict deductions to income-yielding trees in the specific accounting year but encompasses income from the plantation as a whole.

holdings.text: Expenditure on superintendence, weeding etc. of the whole rubber estate, including immature non-yielding areas, is deductible against profits earned as revenue expenditure in the process of earning income.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies distinction between capital (acquisition of asset) and revenue (earning process) expenditure; upkeep of existing plantation is operational revenue expense deductible regardless of immediate yield.

holdings.text: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. CIT is not applicable as it concerned capital payments for acquiring an enduring lease advantage, unlike revenue upkeep of an existing rubber plantation.

anchor.surface_text: But that case has no relevancy to the facts of the present case nor has that passage any applicability to the facts of the present case. The question there was whether certain payments made were by way of capital expenditure or revenue expenditure. The assessee acquired a lease from Government for twenty years and in addition to paying the rent and royalties for the lease the assessee had to pay two further sums as protection fees under the terms of the lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent on facts: capital for new asset acquisition vs. revenue for maintaining existing income-earning plantation structure.

holdings.text: Vallambrosa Rubber Co. Ltd. v. Farmer supports deductibility of estate-wide expenses including non-bearing rubber areas under analogous income tax provisions.

anchor.surface_text: In a somewhat similar case Vallambrosa Rubber Co. Ltd. v. Farmer the expenditure of the kind now claimed was allowed under the corresponding provision of the English Income-tax Act. In that case a rubber company had an estate in which in the year of assessment only 1/7 produced rubber and the other 6/7 was in process of cultivation for the production of rubber.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows persuasive English precedent with identical facts (rubber plantation, partial immature areas), allowing full estate upkeep as deductible against assessable profits.

Farmer the expenditure of the kind now claimed was allowed under the corresponding provision of the English Income-tax Act. In that case a rubber company had an estate in which in the year of assessment only 1/7 produced rubber and the other 6/7 was in process of cultivation for the production of rubber.
